NewWords.WordPhrase: from time to time; sometimes 断断续续地;有时
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It has been raining off and on for a week.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 可能(性)
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Is there any possibility of your getting to London this week?

NewWords.WordPhrase: become established 生根，确立
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The newly planted vines quickly took hold.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sb. ) become tired and lose interest 使(人)厌烦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I hope you're not getting bored listening to me.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. join or connect together; bring in the mind 使联系起来;使联想
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Through science we've got the idea of associating progress with future.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a piece of work that is given to a particular person (分配的)工作，任务，作业
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I hardly ever take pictures except on assignment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: produce 编写;生产，制造
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The company turns out new computer games at a great rate.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. very great pain or suffering of mind or body (身心的)极度痛苦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The wounded man was in agony.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. give as a share or duty 分配，分派
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Those rooms have been assigned to us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. expect 预期，期望
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The police had anticipated trouble from the soccer fans and were at the ground in large numbers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. boring and lasting for a long time 乏味的;冗长的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The tedious play put the audience to sleep.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 名声;名誉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is a man of good reputation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. lack of power, skill or ability 无能，无力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her inability to concentrate could cause an accident.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. fill (sb.) with confidence, eagerness, etc. 激励，鼓舞
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The last leaf on the tree that never fell off inspired the dying patient with the will to live on.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (too) serious and careful in manner and behavior; based on correct or accepted rules 刻板的，拘谨的;正式的，正规的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Business letters are usually formal, but we write in an informal way to family members or friends.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (often disapproving) fixed in behavior, views or methods; strict 一成不变的;严格的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My father is very rigid in his thinking.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. very much; without hope 十分，极度;绝望地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The story is hopelessly confusing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: old-fashioned 过时的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Will denim jeans ever go out of date?

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (usu. disapproving) (of a person) too formal or correct in behavior and showing a dislike of anything rude; neat 古板的，拘谨的;循规蹈矩的;整洁的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Those young ladies are much too prim and proper to enjoy such a rude joke.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 古板地，拘谨地;循规蹈矩地;整洁地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When the boss came in, all the workers were sitting there primly.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. completely plain; causing very great pain, difficulty, worry, etc. 朴素的;严重的，剧烈的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Shortages of staff are very severe in some places.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. tie 领带
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He likes to ware narrow neckties.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 颌，颚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Which jaw moves up and down when you talk?

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 滑稽的;喜剧的   n. 连环漫画(册)
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Most of these trips had exciting or comic moments.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 古物,古玩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He can tell a real antique from a fake one.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. try to deal with 处理，应付
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I don't know how to tackle this problem.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 散文，小品文;论说文
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The other day I came across an interesting essay on the war with Napoleon.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. divide and give out among people, places, etc. 分发，分配，分送
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In the move most of the furniture was left to the neighbors or distributed among friends.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. at last 最终，终于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Finally, I should like to thank you all for coming and to wish you a pleasant journey home.

NewWords.WordPhrase: be brave enough to accept or deal with 勇敢地接受或对付
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She must face up to the fact that she is no longer young.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. look through quickly 浏览，粗略地看
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He scanned the newspaper while having his breakfast.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 意大利式细面条
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many people consider spaghetti as their favored food.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a name given to a book, film, etc. 标题，题目   vt. give a name to 给…加标题，加题目于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The book was first published in 1969 under the title of "Life and Death".

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. very unusual or strange 不同寻常的;奇特的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is a man of extraordinary talents.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 一连串相关的事物; 次序，顺序
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A sequence of bad harvests forced some African countries to ask for foreign aid.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a picture formed in the mind 形象; 印象;(图)像
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I had this image of London in my head which was totally different from how it really is.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a fully grown person or animal 成年人;成年动物
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The adults in the family like the world news section.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 心情;幽默，诙谐
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is in a good humor today.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. bring back to the mind; remember 回想起，回忆起
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I don't recall his name or where I met him.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 论据，论点;争论
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There are many arguments against smoking.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (of behavior, appearance, etc.) socially acceptable 可敬的;体面的;文雅的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Are these clothes respectable enough for Mrs Whitehouse's party?

NewWords.WordPhrase: write down 写下
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Here's my address -- put it down before you forget it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (lit) bring back into the mind; experience again 再现;再次经历
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They took a second honeymoon and tried to recapture the their earlier happiness.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. experience again, esp. in one's imagination 再体验，重温
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. That was an experience I should not like to relive.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. act against 违背，违反
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They violated the ceasefire（停火）agreement.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. write or create (music, poetry, etc.) 创作
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He teaches music and also composes music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: hand in (work that one has done) 交(作业)
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. For your final grade, each of you must turn in a 7-page paper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. , v. 命令，指令
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The officer commanded his men to fire.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. punishment; order kept (among school-children, soldiers, etc.) 惩罚，处分;纪律
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The army was criticized for its harsh discipline.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in addition, more importantly 而且，此外;更有甚者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. How can you love this man? He watches TV all day long, and what's more, he seems not to have brushed his teeth for months!

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 轻视，轻蔑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many voters hold their politicians in contempt.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. making or being made fun of 嘲笑，嘲弄;被戏弄
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I know that ridicule may be a shield, but it is not a weapon.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. sincere, frank 诚挚的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was open-hearted in his wish to help us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: prevent the expression of (feelings, tears, etc.) 控制(感情、眼泪等)
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She kept trying to hold back her tears.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. keep or get away from 避免
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The pilots had to take emergency action to avoid a disaster.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. act of showing or proving sth. 表明;证明
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Can you give us a simple demonstration of gravity?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 生涯，事业;职业
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We can learn much by reading about the careers of great men.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 印，图章
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Please put a seal on the box.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the most important quality of a thing 本质;精髓
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Accuracy is one of the essence of the English language.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (usu.pl) expression of joy for sb.'s success, luck, etc. 祝贺，恭喜
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We offer our congratulations on her success.
